Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit: Argonaute (AGO) proteins are key effectors of RNA-mediated gene silencing and act by binding to miRNAs to repress the expression of target genes at transcriptional or posttranscriptional levels. Whereas AGOs were previously thought to exclusively repress miRNA target genes, the PI's group recently discovered that Arabidopsis AGO10 specifically sequesters a single miRNA class, miR166 to positively regulate their targets. The mechanism of this regulation is unclear, but it may involve proteins that interact with AGO10. Preliminary studies identified several novel cofactors of AGO10, including two serine and arginine enriched splicing factors(SRSFs) and an AGO10-Interacting exoribonuclease (AGIER1), among others. These new findings interconnect RNA silencing with many previously unappreciated biological events such as mRNA splicing and AGO-channeled miRNA decay. To investigate these novel modes of AGO10 regulation, two specific objectives will be pursued: 1) Investigate the biochemical interaction between AGO10 and the SRSFs and its biological consequences; 2) Investigate how AGIER1 affects AGO10-miR166 function. Results will establish how AGO10/miR166 function is modulated and will reveal new layers of complexity in gene regulatory networks through miRNA function.

Broader Impacts: The research provides unique and advanced training opportunities for undergraduates, and graduate students in broad areas. Research and educational objectives are integrated in this CAREER proposal through two strategies: 1) to recruit and train female and minority undergraduates for graduate studies in biochemical and genetic areas; and 2) to modernize and improve the quality of graduate training in RNA biology in classroom and research settings. These efforts will contribute to providing a creative and highly skilled workforce to support the U.S. economy.

POR.DRECONTENT:
RNA silencing regulates plant growth and development, stress responses, and antiviral defense. RNA silencing is guided by small regulatory RNA molecules called miRNA or siRNAs. In plants, the molecules can be widely engineered in agricultural crops for better yield and quality. The common biochemical processes of RNA silencing include the biogenesis of small RNAs by Dicer proteins or Dicer-like proteins, and the incorporation of small RNAs into Argonaute (AGO)-centered RNA-induced silencing complexes (RISCs). The RISCs can either inhibit production of mRNAs or cleave target mRNAs or inhibit protein translation once the mRNAs are produced.The Arabidopsis genome encodes nine functional AGO proteins, among which, AGO1 is a principal slicer in RNA silencing pathways. AGO10, the closest paralog of AGO1, plays a critical role in shoot apical meristem (SAM) development. Whereas AGOs were previously thought to exclusively repress miRNA target genes, AGO10 specifically, and almost exclusively, sequesters a single miRNA class, miR165/166, to preclude them from functioning in the canonical AGO1-mediated pathway for inhibition of gene expression. Based on this groundbreaking work, this NSF CAREER project further investigated the function and mechanism of AGO10-miR166 in plants. 

 

            The NSF CAREER grant has led to 18 peer-reviewed publications, most of which are in top-tier journals. Key outcomes included: 1) we have defined the clear spatiotemporal interaction between AGO10 and miR166, and found that AGO10 quenches miR166 that is produced outside but moves into the AGO10-expressing niche to maintain SAM development.  2) we decoded AGO10-protein interactome, among which are RICE1 (RISC-Interacting Clearing Exoribonuclease1) and RICE2.  We found that the RICE proteins specifically degrade single-strand RNAs but positively regulate miRNA accumulation in vivo. It turns out that the true targets of RICEs in vivo are the uridylated mRNA cleavage products that are produced by RISC. By doing this, RICE proteins maintain functional RISC and secure miRNA sheltering in RISC in vivo. Thus, this study provides insight into the coordination between decay of cleaved target mRNAs and miRNA stability in eukaryotes. 3) Besides AGO10 protein, we also deciphered AGO3-centered RISC, and surprisingly found that AGO3 predominantly bound 24-nt sRNAs with 5? terminal adenine. This result refers that AGO3 is a component in the epigenetic pathway, rather than the prevailingly hypothesized posttranscriptional pathway in the cytoplasm. 4) while studying nine miR166 family genes, we for the first time illustrated the clear biochemical mechanism of plant miRNA processing. Specifically, DCL1 complexes canonically cut pri-miRNAs at a distance of 16~17 base pairs (bp) away from a reference single-stranded/double-stranded junction regions. DCL1 could also finely-adjust processing sites toward an internal loop through its helicase domain. Furthermore, the terminal-branched pri-miRNAs reduce miRNA production because DCL1 complexes can cut pri-miRNAs from loop to base, destroying the pri-miRNA substrates. 5) we further conducted proteomic analysis of DCL1, HYL1 and SE and identified numerous new auxiliary factors for each of these components. For instance, KETCH1, an importin β-protein is a new cofactor of HYL1. We found thatthat KETCH1 specifically transports HYL1 into the nucleus to facilitate miRNA production. 6) Due to increasing visibility and authority of our team in the RNA field, we have been invited to write several comprehensive reviews and previews for top-tier journals. 

 

            This NSF CAREER grant has also significant broader of impacts: First of all, we have trained four female graduate students. For instance, Dr. Fuqu Hu has the co-1st authorships in two papers in Cell and in eLife. She was awarded John Mack Prescott Award, the highest award to graduate student in department of Biochemistry and Biophysics. Now she works in a high-tech company in the US. Dr. Claudia Castillo has the 1stauthorships in eLife, Plant J., Developmental Cell, and Cell Host & Microbe, and co-authorships in Nature Structural and molecular Biology, Bio-protocol, Nature, Developmental Cell and others in the pipeline.  She won the Vice Chancellor?s award, the highest award to graduate students in Texas A&M. She also won Norman Borlaug Outstanding Graduate Student award. She is now ready moving to next stage of her academic career. Second, this grant also provided opportunities to ~60 undergraduate students who have been doing research credits or summer REU projects in my lab. Among these undergraduate students, Jamie Gutierrez and Marvin Wirianto, have attended Texas A&M University (TAMU)-wide undergraduate research competition in 2017, and won the first and second prizes, respectively?these are the highest honors for undergraduates in TAMU. Of special note, Ms. Karissa Yamaguchi, was named one of two winners of the Brown-Rudder Award for 2019, which is the highest honor bestowed upon a graduating senior at Texas A&M University. Last but not least, we have actively collaborated with scientists who work in non-model organisms, and transformed our knowledge gained from Arabidopsis into agriculturally or economically important crops and plants, and published numerous important papers in the peer-reviewed journals.
